comment.author: 66847065@N00
comment._content: Is that snow by the buildings?

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: How sure are you about that street sign, artolog? I can't make it out. (Edit: I could make out the "5", so never mind the next paragraph.) 52nd street would make this a block or so away from St. Patrick's, which would explain the crowd. OTOH, I can see a sign for "Benguiat and Keresey" across the street, which according to this ( chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-11-24/ed-... ) was located at 47th and 5th Ave. Could just be an advertisement, I guess. I tried to find this block on Google's street view and I couldn't find anything recognizable. All the buildings with distinct character have either been torn down or had their facades replaced with 60's style square fronts, including that one on the left with the turret windows.

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Rjones, I came to the same conclusion. Benguiat and Keresey was in the Windsor Arcade at 569 Fifth Ave and liquidated in 1916, according to Country life in America, Volume 29 (on Google Books). The only thing I can add is that this view is looking north.

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Here's an interesting view from about this spot but looking the other way, in 1965 and in 2010. www.flickr.com/photos/barbararich/5190091189/

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I've grabbed a few of Caesar1956's Id's from this picture for large buildings in the distance. You have to download the .tiff file from the persistent URL above to see these in this photo. See if you agree. The Easter photo above is taken looking north towards Central Park from the west side of 5th ave., south of 52d St.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: You certainly can see that turret on the Hotel New Netherland off in the distance, even on the photo above.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91829349@N00] 
I think the buildings on the east side of 5th between 54th and 55th are the same, many with new facades.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Excellent detective work, all! Agreed that the street sign reads W. 52nd Street and we are looking north up Fifth Ave. Based on that location, St. Patrick's Cathedral is off to the right of and behind the photographer, as it is between E. 50th and E. 51st, so that does explain the density of the crowd! According to the 1914 American Art Directory, Benguiat & Keresey had a gallery at 657 Fifth Ave., so that is definitely their oriental rug gallery in the photo. They may have had multiple locations or moved from the other location. Thanks again for all the careful looking. We will add more description to the record when we update.
